title: Stool, "Puffo", ca. 1970
provenance: The Linda and Irwin R. Berman Stool Collection; 2008: acquired by Museum
creditline: The Linda and Irwin R. Berman Stool Collection
description: Soft black cylindrical foam body with domed top.
justification:
In Italy throughout the 1960s-70s, radical design groups were established in oposition to the functionalism of the International Style. Grupo Strum was one of these groups, active in Turin, Italy, between 1966-75. The name is abreviated from "archtettura strumentale" (functional architecture). The founders were all architects, graduates of Turin Politechnico: Georgio Ceretti (Domodossola, verbeno-Cusio-Ossola, b. 1932), Pietro Derossi (Turin, b. 1933), Carlo Giammarco (Pescarra, b. 1940), Riccardo Rosso (Turin, b. 1941), Maurizio Vogliazzo(Turin, b. 1943). The group promoted theoretical studies and seminars that played role in development of the Antidesign and Radical Architecture movements.
The Puffo stool is made from a polyurethane foam that has been molded into a simple cylinder. What looks like a rigid, almost bullet-like form rather than a seat, is actually a soft, pliable mass that gives while it supports.
This stool adds to a small group of Italian design in the "Pop" mode, represented by the Cactus coatrack also manufactured by Gufram, and furniture of other materials, by designers such as Gaetano Pesce.
